supporting.text: The adult human skeleton typically consists of 206 bones, as confirmed by anatomical studies and medical textbooks.

attacks.text: The adult human skeleton typically consists of 206 bones, as confirmed by anatomical studies and medical textbooks.
Some individuals have anatomical variations, such as extra ribs or sesamoid bones, which can increase the total bone count beyond 206.
These variations are rare and do not change the standard count of 206 bones in the vast majority of the population.
Children have more bones than adults due to unfused growth plates, which contradicts the claim if interpreted as universally applicable.
The claim implicitly refers to the adult human body, as growth plate fusion is a well-known developmental process.

supporting.text: The count of 206 bones excludes sesamoid bones, which vary in number among individuals but are not part of the standard skeletal count.

attacks.text: The count of 206 bones excludes sesamoid bones, which vary in number among individuals but are not part of the standard skeletal count.
Sesamoid bones are anatomically part of the skeletal system, and their exclusion artificially reduces the true count of bones in the human body.
Standard anatomical definitions classify sesamoid bones as accessory bones, not primary skeletal components, which justifies their exclusion from the standard count.
Some individuals have sesamoid bones in consistent locations (e.g., patella), making their exclusion arbitrary in those cases.

supporting.text: Newborns have approximately 270 bones, some of which fuse together during growth, resulting in the adult count of 206 bones.

attacks.text: Newborns have approximately 270 bones, some of which fuse together during growth, resulting in the adult count of 206 bones.
Some individuals retain extra bones (e.g., sesamoid bones or supernumerary ribs), leading to variations in the total bone count even in adults.
Such variations are rare and do not contradict the general anatomical standard of 206 bones for the typical adult human body.
Pathological conditions like polydactyly or syndactyly can also affect bone count, further complicating the claim.
Pathological cases are exceptions and are not considered in standard anatomical definitions, which focus on typical human physiology.
